doc.after: In the 13th century BC Amman was called Rabbath Ammon or Rabat Amon by the Ammonites. In the Hebrew Bible, it is referred to as Rabbat Ê¿Ammon (Tiberian Hebrew Rabbaá¹¯ Ê¿AmmÃ´n). It was later conquered by the Assyrians, followed by the Persians, and then the Greek Macedonians. Ptolemy II Philadelphus, the Macedonian ruler of Egypt, renamed it Philadelphia (Ancient Greek Î¦Î¹Î»Î±Î´Î­Î»ÏÎµÎ¹Î±). The city became part of the Nabataean kingdom until 106 AD when Philadelphia came under Roman control and joined the Decapolis.[4]
